title: Erdős Problem #788: Sum-Free Subsets in Intervals
description: Estimate f(n) where f(n) is maximal s.t. for all B ⊂ (2n,4n), ∃ C ⊂ (n,2n) sum-free w.r.t. B with |C|+|B| ≥ f(n). Conjectured f(n) ≤ n^{1/2+o(1)}. Known: n^{1/2} ≪ f(n) ≪ (n log n)^{2/3}. OPEN.

overview.historicalContext:
This problem asks about the interplay between sum-free sets and interval arithmetic. Given a 'forbidden' set B in (2n, 4n), we seek a large set C in (n, 2n) whose pairwise sums avoid B. The function f(n) measures the guaranteed combined size |C| + |B|.

Choi (1971) first studied this, proving f(n) ≪ n^{3/4} and conjecturing f(n) ≤ n^{1/2+o(1)}. Adenwalla gave the lower bound f(n) ≫ n^{1/2} via Sidon sets. Hunter improved the upper bound to n^{2/3+o(1)}. Baltz, Schoen, and Srivastav (2000) achieved the current best f(n) ≪ (n log n)^{2/3} using probabilistic methods.
overview.problemStatement: Let f(n) be maximal such that for all B ⊂ (2n,4n) ∩ ℕ, there exists C ⊂ (n,2n) ∩ ℕ with c₁ + c₂ ∉ B for all c₁ ≠ c₂ ∈ C and |C| + |B| ≥ f(n). Estimate f(n). Is f(n) ≤ n^{1/2+o(1)}?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines sum-free sets with respect to a prescribed set, the function f(n) via Nat.find, and Sidon sets. Known bounds are axiomatized: Choi's n^{3/4}, Adenwalla's n^{1/2} lower bound, Hunter's n^{2/3+o(1)}, and BSS's (n log n)^{2/3}. The interval_sum_range theorem is proved directly. Summary theorems combine the known bounds.
keyInsights: Elements of (n, 2n) sum to values in (2n, 4n), making the intervals natural
Sidon sets provide the key lower bound construction (f(n) ≫ n^{1/2})
The gap between n^{1/2} and (n log n)^{2/3} remains open after 50+ years
Choi's conjecture f(n) ≤ n^{1/2+o(1)} is still unresolved
Probabilistic methods give the best upper bounds (BSS 2000)

sections.title: Part 1: Basic Definitions
sections.summary: Open intervals (n,2n) and (2n,4n), pairwise sums, and sum-free with respect to B.

sections.title: Part 2: The Function f(n)
sections.summary: f(n) defined via Nat.find as the maximum guaranteed |C|+|B| over all B.

sections.title: Part 3: Choi's Original Bound (1971)
sections.summary: Choi's upper bound f(n) ≪ n^{3/4} and conjecture f(n) ≤ n^{1/2+o(1)}.

sections.title: Part 4: Adenwalla's Lower Bound
sections.summary: Lower bound f(n) ≫ n^{1/2} via Sidon set construction. Sidon set definition and existence.

sections.title: Part 5: Hunter's Improvement
sections.summary: Hunter's improved upper bound f(n) ≪ n^{2/3+o(1)} via counting arguments.

sections.title: Part 6: Baltz-Schoen-Srivastav Bound (2000)
sections.summary: Best known upper bound f(n) ≪ (n log n)^{2/3} via probabilistic construction of strongly sum-free sets.

sections.title: Part 7: The Gap
sections.summary: Current bounds theorem combining n^{1/2} lower and (n log n)^{2/3} upper. The gap remains open.

sections.title: Part 8: Connections to Sum-Free Sets
sections.summary: Classical sum-free sets, sum-free density, and how Problem 788 generalizes the sum-free concept.

sections.title: Part 9: Interval Constraints
sections.summary: Why sums from (n,2n) land in (2n,4n). Proved theorem interval_sum_range and axiom sums_in_upper_interval.

sections.title: Part 10: Summary
sections.summary: Summary theorem combining bounds, Choi's conjecture status, and historical timeline. OPEN.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #788 remains OPEN. The function f(n) satisfies n^{1/2} ≪ f(n) ≪ (n log n)^{2/3}. Choi's conjecture that f(n) ≤ n^{1/2+o(1)} is unresolved after 50+ years.
conclusion.implications: This problem connects additive combinatorics with the theory of Sidon sets and sum-free sets. The gap between the lower and upper bounds represents a fundamental barrier in understanding sum-free structures in intervals.
openQuestions: Prove or disprove Choi's conjecture f(n) ≤ n^{1/2+o(1)}
Close the gap between n^{1/2} and (n log n)^{2/3}
Determine the exact order of magnitude of f(n)
Find explicit constructions matching the probabilistic bounds
